primary_question: Did the Census Bureau fundamentally change how they estimate state-level international migration between vintages, and does this create comparability issues for time series analysis?

findings.title: Major Methodology Shift at 2010 Transition - Introduction of ROYA Method
findings.conclusion: The Census Bureau fundamentally changed its approach to estimating foreign-born immigration between the 1990s-2000s and the 2010s. The 1990s-2000s methodology relied primarily on residual techniques using decennial census foreign-born counts, while the 2010s introduced the Residence One Year Ago (ROYA) method using American Community Survey data.
findings.uncertainty: The transition is well-documented, but the exact magnitude of impact on state-level estimates is not quantified

key_metrics.name: methodology_eras
key_metrics.interpretation: 2000s residual method, 2010s ROYA method, 2020s ROYA+DHS method

findings.title: Vintage 2024 Introduced DHS Administrative Data Adjustment
findings.conclusion: Vintage 2024 incorporated a major methodological change: using Department of Homeland Security administrative data to adjust ACS-based estimates upward by approximately 75% of estimated humanitarian migrants, changing estimates retroactively back to 2021.
findings.uncertainty: Low - this change is explicitly documented and quantified by Census Bureau

key_metrics.name: nim_revision_2021_2022
key_metrics.interpretation: Increase over previous Vintage 2023 estimates for the 2021-2022 period

key_metrics.name: humanitarian_adjustment_factor
key_metrics.interpretation: Adjustment captured 75% of humanitarian migrants in Census Bureau benchmark database

findings.title: State-Level Allocation May Not Accurately Reflect Humanitarian Migrant Distribution
findings.conclusion: The Census Bureau acknowledges that its method for distributing national NIM estimates to states may not accurately capture where humanitarian migrants are actually settling. Research is ongoing to improve state/county allocation.
findings.uncertainty: High - Census Bureau acknowledges uncertainty but does not quantify potential error at state level

findings.title: Census Bureau Explicitly Warns Against Combining Vintages
findings.conclusion: The Census Bureau explicitly states that data from different vintages should not be combined and that time series comparisons should only be made within a single vintage.
findings.uncertainty: Low - this guidance is explicit and unambiguous in Census Bureau documentation

findings.title: NIM Represents Largest Source of Uncertainty in Population Estimates
findings.conclusion: The Census Bureau acknowledges that net international migration is the most uncertain component of population change estimates, representing approximately 40% of the variance in Demographic Analysis estimates.
findings.uncertainty: Low - well-documented in Census Bureau publications

key_metrics.name: nim_share_of_da_variance
key_metrics.interpretation: NIM accounts for approximately 40% of variance in Demographic Analysis estimates

key_metrics.name: nim_share_of_population
key_metrics.interpretation: NIM comprises only ~12% of total DA resident population under 65, but disproportionate uncertainty

findings.title: Small States Face Additional Accuracy Challenges
findings.conclusion: Research indicates that population projections and estimates are less accurate for smaller population bases due to rate instability when demographic rates are calculated for small cells.
findings.uncertainty: Medium - general principle is established, but specific impact on North Dakota NIM estimates is not quantified

key_metrics.name: north_dakota_population
key_metrics.interpretation: Among smallest state populations in nation

review_requests.question: What statistical approaches are appropriate for detecting and potentially adjusting for methodology-induced level shifts in a time series with only two known transition points and no overlap period?
review_requests.context: The Census Bureau provides no overlapping estimates using both old and new methodologies. We have 10 years pre-2010 and 15 years post-2010, with a known methodology change at the boundary.

review_requests.question: Given that the Census Bureau explicitly warns against combining vintages, under what conditions might it be methodologically defensible to create an extended time series for research purposes?
review_requests.context: Our goal is to extend a migration time series for demographic projection modeling. The Census Bureau's guidance is oriented toward general users.

review_requests.question: Are there established standards or guidelines in demography for minimum population thresholds below which migration estimates become unreliable for time series modeling?
review_requests.context: North Dakota has approximately 800,000 residents and receives perhaps 1,000-3,000 net international migrants annually.

key_uncertainties: Magnitude of methodology-induced level shift at 2009-2010 transition
Accuracy of state-level allocation of national NIM adjustment for North Dakota specifically
Small-state estimation error interaction with methodology changes
Whether 2000s residual method systematically over/under-estimated NIM relative to ROYA method
